awd_titl_txt: CNO Solar Neutrinos with Borexino - A Quest For Ultra-Low Background
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar neutrino research has already discovered massive neutrinos and flavor mixing and is moving into an era where precision measurements can provide a unique probe of the structure and composition of the Sun. The carbon-nitrogen-oxygen (CNO) cycle is one of the fusion reactions by which stars convert hydrogen to helium, releasing electron-neutrinos. The CNO neutrino flux depends on the abundance of carbon in the core of the Sun. A measurement of the CNO flux would be the first direct measurement of the solar metallicity (the abundance of elements other than hydrogen or helium) in the core of the Sun. It could test the fundamental assumption of homogeneity in the Sun and provide crucial information regarding opacities in the solar interior that are important for helioseismology. Such studies could thus have a great impact on our understanding of the Sun, stellar astrophysics, the link between planetary and stellar formation, as well as basic neutrino physics. Borexino is a liquid scintillator detector, located at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in Italy, with a unique sensitivity to solar neutrinos.

The Borexino research program has involved many undergraduate and graduate students. Mentoring and training these younger researchers from Princeton and other schools is a high priority. The group is actively promoting women in science through Princeton Women in Physics.

This award provides funding for the Princeton U. group to continue to improve the sensitivity and to assist in the operation of the Borexino detector. Borexino's sensitivity to solar neutrinos is due primarily to the extremely low background made possible after reducing backgrounds in the liquid scintillator by re-purification. The methods and equipment for purification operations were provided by Princeton, as was the staff that managed the operations. Further reduction of the scintillator background is possible with modest improvements of the purification system and with the additional scintillator purification operations planned here. With these changes, Borexino will be in a good position to make the first measurement of CNO neutrinos. Future data with lower background will also result in improvements of the earlier Borexino measurements of pp, pep, Be-7, and B-8 neutrinos. The future measurement of all solar neutrinos will map out with higher sensitivity the vacuum-to-matter-effect dependence of neutrino oscillations on the neutrino energy, as well as search for non-standard interactions.

por.por_cntn:
Borexino is a large underground liquid scintillation detector primarily designed to observe low-energy neutrinos produced by the sun, to study the composition and structure of the Sun using solar neutrinos as probes. The detector started data-taking in May 2007 and ended in October 2021. It is located in the Hall C of Laboratori de Gran Sasso at Assergi, L'Aquila, Italy. Its main component is around 300 tons of ultra-pure liquid scintillator. 

The Sun burns hydrogen into helium at its core region and produces neutrinos along. Thus the solar neutrino rates can be used to measure the burning rates. There are two ways of conversion hydrogen burning, the proton-proton(pp) chain, and the Carbon-Nitrogen-Oxygen (CNO) cycle. In a pp-chain way, four protons are converted to one helium nucleon in several steps. In the CNO-cycle way, carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen are catalysts and not consumed. 

The Standard Solar Models (SSMs) are models built based on a few assumptions to predict the evolution of the Sun. The parameters are calibrated against various data, such as the brightness of the Sun and the spectroscopy of the solar photosphere. The SSMs are also important references in the construction of other stellar models. Currently, two types of SSMs are well recognized. The first type of model is called the high metallicity model. It reproduces the helioseismology data, or the variation of the brightness of the Sun due to mechanical waves, well. The second type of model is called the low metallicity model. The second type is improved in several aspects compared with the first one but lost the match of the sub-percent precision measurement of the helioseismology data. improvement. The two models differs in the assumption of the metallicity, or the abundances of metals (the elements heavier than helium), at the solar core region, due to poor knowledge of them.

In the past, photons are the tools used to study the Sun. Because of the high density and opacity of the Sun, information about the core region carried by photons is lost in the collision before photons escape from the Sun. Neutrinos, instead, escape from the Sun with seldom interactions and thus can be used to study the solar core region directly.

It is challenging to measure the solar neutrinos because their signal energy range overlaps heavily with the common natural radio activities. In 1989, when Borexino was proposed, it was designed to purify the liquid scintillator and to use nylon vessels to isolate the purified liquid scintillator from Radon. With the support of NSF and other funding agencies, Borexino succeeded in achieving the unprecedented radio-purity of uranium and thorium backgrounds. In 2011, the collaboration conducted another dedicated purification campaign, and further reduced the background level to better than 10-24 g/g, which is smaller than an egg compared with the Moon. In 2016, the Borexino collaboration presented a comprehensive measurement of the pp-chain solar neutrinos.

The rate of neutrinos produced in the CNO cycle depends on the carbon and nitrogen abundances at the solar core region and thus may provide hints to the solar metallicity problem. In this grant, our group worked on the measurement of CNO solar neutrinos with Borexino.

The challenge of measuring CNO neutrinos with Borexino is to disentangle CNO with the 210Bi backgrounds. They cannot be distinguished from the shape of the distribution of event energy, but the 210Bi rate can be determined from its decay daughter 210Po, and 210Po event rates can be measured with high precision in the absence of convection motion of the liquid scintillator.

It is challenging to maintain the stability of such a big object as the Borexino detector. Several improvements were applied to improve the thermal stability aiming at suppressing the convection motion of the liquid scintillator, including installation of thermal insulation layers, and active temperature control systems. Yet at last, we succeeded in reducing the variation of the detector temperature to be less than 0.05oC. Before achieving the complete absence of convection, a moving low convection region has been formed. We developed a method called the Low Polonium Field analysis correcting the residual movement of the region, and finding a limit of the 210Po rate adequate to reject the no-CNO assumption.

In 2020, we published the experimental evidence to neutrinos produced in the CNO cycle. This is the first time we proved experimentally the theory proposed by Carl von Weizsacker and Hans Bethe in the late 1930s. In 2021, the collaboration is awarded the 2021 Giuseppe and Vanna Cocconi Prize for this work.

The observation of pp-chain and CNO neutrinos are providing invaluable information to address the long-lasting solar metallicity problem and for neutrino physics through the measurement of the electron neutrino survival probability.
